fields.label_text:
BADA 2004 Exhibition label:
TEAPOT
Anodised aluminium, Australia, 2001, designed and made by Robert Foster (b. 1962)
This teapot is a recent acquisition for the V&A.  Robert Foster trained as a silversmith and has established a reputation both as a designer and metalworker.  Silversmithing and metalworking in Australia is not inhibited by the traditions and regulations that exist in Europe.  Artists are therefore able to use a diversity of materials, combining precious and base metals, which are often flamboyantly coloured.  Over the past 25 years Australian trained silversmiths have increasingly gained international recognition for the innovative and high-quality work they produce. Foster is a leader amongst them.

M.29-2001

TEAPOT
Anodised aluminium in blue and purple
Canberra, Australia, 2001
Robert Foster

This stunning teapot is by the Australian silversmith, Robert Foster who has an established reputation both as a designer and metalsmith. 
Australian gold and silversmithing over the past 25 years has increasingly gained international recognition for its level of innovation and quality. Australian silversmithing and metalwork operates within an environment which is uninhibited by the traditions and regulations of the more traditional European centres. It is therefore able to encompass a diversity of materials, combining precious and base metals which are often flamboyantly coloured. Some of the most innovative and exciting contemporary metalwork is being produced by Australian trained silversmiths and Foster is a leader amongst them.

M.29-2001

fields.descriptive_line: Teapot and lid, anodised aluminium in deep blue and purple, designed and made by Robert Foster, Canberra, Australia, 2001.

fields.name: The Silver Galleries, International Silver, 1800 to the Present Day

fields.physical_description: Double spout teapot in anodised and polished aluminium, the body, anodised blue, rises from a small elliptical base, internally welded to the walls which twist and flare outwards towards an  everted, elliptical rim which is set at 45° to the horizontal, the back panel thus curves inwards towards the top and the front panel correspondingly curves outwards.  The mouth of the vessel narrows to two, diametrically opposite V shaped points, the culmination of two arced channels down each side of the body which form the two spouts.  The vessel is stabilised by a cast and polished aluminium handle in the form of a rod, oval in cross section which rises in an arc from the floor and curves away from the vertical, passing through the body, just beneath the rim and tapering to a point as it emerges on the opposite side. The handle is secured by a rivet which is attached to an internal lug, immediately on the inside of the rim.  The lid, anodised a rich purple, is slightly concave in cross section and elliptical in outline to follow the rim of the body.  The points end in semicircular cut out to allow for the flow of liquid.  The handle for the lid is an inverted U shaped section of polished aluminium, attached through the centre of the lid by two rivets from the underside, each in a rubber sleeve which grip the handle when closed.  The section of the handle which passes through the body serves as a support for the detachable lid.  At the mid point there are two notches, each on either side which serve to locate the rubber sleeves.
fields.dimensions: [Teapot] length: 13.50 cm base, maximum, height: 26.00 cm maximum, width: 7.00 cm maximum

M.29-2001 [26/11/2002]
fields.public_access_description:
This aluminium teapot is an example of the innovative and exciting contemporary metalwork produced by Australian-trained silversmiths. Robert Foster (b.1962), one of Australia’s leading metalsmiths, designed and made it. 

Foster is one of the Australian designers who have increasingly gained international recognition over the past 25 years. They are not bound by the traditions and regulations of the more traditional European centres and enjoy experimenting with diverse materials, combining precious and base metals which are often flamboyantly coloured.
fields.exhibition_history:
The Silver Galleries, International Silver, 1800 to the Present Day (Victoria and Albert Museum 26/11/2002-26/11/2002)
BADA Fair (01/03/2004-31/03/2004)

Dietrich, Gerhard <u>Drei Silberschmiede, drei Lander: (Edel-) Metall aktuell: Werner Bunck, Deutschland, Robert Foster, Australien, Michael Rowe, England: the eloquent vessel</u>, Cologne, Museum fur Angewandte Kunst, 1992
Published on the occasion of an exhibition held at the Museum fur Angewandte Kunst, Cologne, 1992.  Parallel text in German and English
